column1: Tyeller (singular tyellë) is the Quenya word for "grade
column2: order; a step in a stairway

column1: In the Tengwar system of writing
column2: the Tyeller were the six "grades" used to indicate modifications to a basic sound in Tengwar and represented six modes of articulation in the mouth.

column1: The Tyeller were signified by the length of the telco and the number of the lúvar (one or two). Some specialized Tengwar modes had eight tyeller instead of six
extended telco both above and below the line.

column2: where the first tyellë referred to the basic patakar
column6: the following tyeller would typically represent modifications of their basic sounds.

column2: in the sequence known as tincotéma
column3: the next tyeller would normally represent the dental sounds like nd

column1: It is also one of the few words ending in -e which forms the plural in -r
